div.p:
Letter not found. The text given here is extracted from Tkach, Neubauer & Roser (2022), Brief 33, W. Sonder to D. von Schlechtendal, 10 January 1859. The extract is introduced by 'Von Dr. F. Müller hatte ich gestern einen vom 16 Nov. datirten Brief.' [Yesterday I received a letter from Dr. F. Mueller, dated 16 November]
[Er ist überaus beschäftigt mit seinem Garten. Der Prinz Paul Wilhelm war längere Zeit dort u verkehrte viel mit Dr. Müller. Die östreichische Fregatte war in Sidney angekommen. Dr. Müller erwartete sie in Melbourne. Es sollte gerade eine Kiste mit Drucksachen u Pflanzen für mich abgehen. — Ich sende Ihnen hierbei eine Doublette vom 2 Heft der Transact. der pharmac. Society; es ist darin ein Rhus beschrieben u wird es Sie vielleicht interessieren zu lesen, wie wenig die englischen Apotheken geneigt sind Reformen in der Pharmacie anzunehmen....

[He is extremely busy with his garden. Prince Paul Wilhelm was there for a long time and had many conversations with Dr. Mueller.
Prince Paul Wilhelm of Württemberg; see M to E. Fenzl, 14 September 1858. The Austrian frigate had arrived in Sidney.
An Austrian scientific expedition visited Australia and New Zealand in Novara . See Scherzer (1861-2). Dr Mueller was expecting her in Melbourne. A crate with printed matter and plants was about to leave for me. — I am sending you herewith a duplicate of the second part of the Transactions of the Pharmaceutical Society; a Rhus is described in it
Rhus rhodanthema, (B58.04.01, p. 43). and it may interest you to read how little the English pharmacies are inclined to accept reforms in pharmacy.
This is not available on line, so I can't gloss the comment "… how little the English pharmacies are inclined to accept reforms in pharmacy." It really should have a gloss. I assume it is in another part of the issue where M described the Rhus. Said to be at Monash University. I seem to remember that you checked some entries in Ms pubs list at School of Pharmacy site.
]
Sonder then answers questions Schlechtendal had evidently asked about M publications previously received (German text at Tkach, Neubauer & Roser (2022), p. 152):
The Fragmenta phytographiae. Australasiae is a small independent work, I received the end of the first part via London a few days ago. Our copies of it will probably arrive with the next consignment of plants [B57.07.01: fascicle 3 of Fragmenta was accompanied by a title page indicating that it completed vol. 1, but when issued as a bound volume (B60.02.04), vol. 1 comprised the first 10 fascicles; see Darragh & Lucas (2015), pp. 303-4]. The Introduction of useful Plants into Victoria, [B58.05.02] as well as An historical Review of the Explorations of Australia [B58.05.03] are from the Transactions of the Philosophical Institute. Victoria Vol. II. Part II. I also received: Papers of the Royal Society of Tasmania 1857 p. 227. On Two alpine Eurybiae of the Australian Continent by Dr Ferd. Mueller. [B60.13.03: the paper is dated 'Botanic Gardens, Melbourne, January 1857' and was probably read at a meeting of the Society in February 1857; M evidently received page proofs before the volume was issued, and Sonder then lists the species described] On Australian & Tasmanian Umbelliferous Plants by Dr. F. Müller [B60.13.02; Sonder summarizes the content and lists species discussed, and Schlechtendal published a lightly edited version of Sonder's summary in 'Literatur. Papers of the Royal Society of Tasmania. 1857', Botanische Zeitung, 11 February 1859, p. 56, which also mentioned the Eurybia paper and listed the new species 'nach gütiger Mittheilung des Hrn. Dr. Sonder' [according to the friendly notification of Dr Sonder]. ...
